description:
In a world where humans coexist with androids called Neans, a group known as the Immortal Nine rises up against society. Tasked with disposing of the revolters, a Nean named Rouge Redstar (aka Metal Rouge) and investigator Naomi Orthmann head to Mars to track them down…but first, Rouge wants some chocolate.

(Source: Crunchyroll)

tags.name: Robots
tags.description: Prominently features humanoid machines.

tags.name: Artificial Intelligence
tags.description: Intelligent non-organic machines that work and react similarly to humans.

tags.name: Henshin
tags.description: Prominently features character or costume transformations which often grant special abilities.

tags.name: Cyberpunk
tags.description: Set in a future of advanced technological and scientific achievements that have resulted in social disorder.

tags.name: Female Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is female.

tags.name: Primarily Adult Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

tags.name: Tanned Skin
tags.description: Prominently features characters with tanned skin.

tags.name: Assassins
tags.description: Centers around characters who murder people as a profession.

tags.name: Super Power
tags.description: Prominently features characters with special abilities that allow them to do what would normally be physically or logically impossible.

tags.name: Fugitive
tags.description: Prominently features a character evading capture by an individual or organization.

tags.name: Dystopian
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a society characterized by poverty, squalor or oppression.

tags.name: Conspiracy
tags.description: Contains one or more factions controlling or attempting to control the world from the shadows.

tags.name: Martial Arts
tags.description: Centers around the use of traditional hand-to-hand combat.

tags.name: Memory Manipulation
tags.description: Prominently features a character(s) who has had their memories altered.

tags.name: Urban
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a city.

tags.name: Tokusatsu
tags.description: Prominently features elements that resemble special effects in Japanese live-action shows

tags.name: Crime
tags.description: Centers around unlawful activities punishable by the state or other authority.

tags.name: Class Struggle
tags.description: Contains conflict born between the different social classes. Generally between an dominant elite and a suffering oppressed group.

tags.name: Space
tags.description: Partly or completely set in outer space.

tags.name: Espionage
tags.description: Prominently features characters infiltrating an organization in order to steal sensitive information.

tags.name: Guns
tags.description: Prominently features the use of guns in combat.

tags.name: Aliens
tags.description: Prominently features extraterrestrial lifeforms.

tags.name: CGI
tags.description: Prominently features scenes created with computer-generated imagery.

tags.name: Super Robot
tags.description: Prominently features large robots often piloted by hot-blooded protagonists.

tags.name: Dissociative Identities
tags.description: A case where one or more people share the same body.

tags.name: Drugs
tags.description: Prominently features the usage of drugs such as opioids, stimulants, hallucinogens etc.

tags.name: Tomboy
tags.description: Features a girl who exhibits characteristics or behaviors considered in many cultures to be typical of boys.

tags.name: Spearplay
tags.description: Prominently features the use of spears in combat.

tags.name: Twins
tags.description: Prominently features two or more siblings that were born at one birth.

node.description:
A notable mechanical and character designer for both anime and tokusatsu series.

He aspired a career in the industry after having seen [Space Battleship Yamato](https://anilist.co/anime/1650/), a franchise in which he would eventually serve as a director [in 2012](https://anilist.co/anime/12029/). His career began in 1978, debuting as a mechanical designer on [Toushou Daimos](https://anilist.co/anime/2816/), designing the enemy robots. Few years later in 1981, he made his tokusatsu debut on Robot 8-chan.

The following decade he worked on industry shaping series such as [Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/86/), [Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1089/) and [Patlabor](https://anilist.co/anime/324/). During this time he also had ties to Parallel Creation, a creative group led by sci-fi writer [Aritsune Toyota](https://anilist.co/staff/220367/). This led him to work as an illustrator on novels such as [Record of Lodoss War](https://anilist.co/manga/92655/), in which his designs were deeply influential for Japanese fantasy series.

In 2002, he directed [RahXephon](https://anilist.co/anime/165/), an anime original created by him. Izubuchi said that his attempt was to set a new standard for mecha anime, as well as to bring back aspects of '70s mecha shows like [Brave Raideen](https://anilist.co/anime/2128/).

A trademark in his mechanical designs is the Buchi-hole (ブチ穴), a series of round holes embedded, usually in a cluster pattern of three holes above and two below, located somewhere on the mecha.

__Hobby:__ Basketball

__[Website](https://taisei-iwasaki.com/)__ | __[Spotify](https://open.spotify.com/artist/2eutad3VCXdembmIgWdwjH)__

__Taisei Iwasaki__ is a Japanese musician, composer and [gekiban](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%8A%87%E4%BC%B4) writer. He is known for composing music for various media like movies, dramas, commercials and anime. He mentions that his father is from Hakodate, and claims the city to be one of his favorites.

His hobby is basketball, and in regards to his hobby, he provides songs for [NBA](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA)-programs.

A co-founder and a board member of [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/).

Upon graduating from high school, Kawamoto was first employed in the making and designing of precision machinery. During this early period, he became interested in becoming an animator due to the ongoing [Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1088/) series, [Yoshiyuki Tomino](https://anilist.co/staff/97337/)'s [Mobile Suit Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/80/) and [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/)'s amateur [Daicon](https://anilist.co/anime/2724/) films. In particular, [Yoshikazu Yasuhiko](https://anilist.co/staff/97220/)'s work was a major influence.

After graduating, he applied for a small sub-contracting studio called Group Donguri and was accepted. In 1986, he made his debut in Yasuhiko's 1986 film [Arion](https://anilist.co/anime/791/). During the production he was mentored by the character designer [Sachiko Kamimura](https://anilist.co/staff/112663/), with whom he would later work with on multiple occasions, including being her assistant in [Venus Wars](https://anilist.co/anime/544/), which was also written and directed by Yasuhiko. After this Kawamoto worked on numerous series by [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/), most notably as a character designer on the Gundam entries, [Stardust Memory](https://anilist.co/anime/84/) and [The 08th MS Team](https://anilist.co/anime/81/), as well as the internationally acclaimed [Cowboy Bebop](https://anilist.co/anime/1/).

In 1998, he co-founded Bones with fellow Sunrise staff members [Masahiko Minami](https://anilist.co/staff/101519/) and [Hiroshi Ousaka](https://anilist.co/staff/107410/). Some of the more recent works he has provided designs for include [Wolf's Rain](https://anilist.co/anime/202/), [Ghost Slayers Ayashi](https://anilist.co/anime/1587/), [Noragami](https://anilist.co/anime/20447/) and [Kekkai Sensen](https://anilist.co/anime/20727/).

**Non-anime staff credits:**
~!
- Character Design - "Gigantic Drive" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Kidou Senshi Gundam A year of War" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Kidou Senshi Gundam Cross Dimension 0079" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Kidou Senshi Gundam F91 Formula Senki 0122" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Kidou Senshi Gundam Return of Zion" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Kidou Senshi Gundam Senki" (Video game)
- Character Design - "OUT LIVE Be Eliminate Yesterday" (Video game)
- Character Design - "OUT LIVE" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Wonder Project J" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Robot Alchemic Drive" (Video game)
- Assistant Chief Animation Director - "OVER THE MONOCHROME RAINBOW" (Video game)
- Animation Director - "Ghost in the Shell" (Video game)
- Animation Director - "Kidou Senshi Gundam" (Video game)
- Key Animation for "Ghost in the Shell" (Video game)
- Key Animation - "Kidou Senshi Gundam Cross Dimension 0079" (Video game)
- Key Animation - "Kidou Senshi Gundam PERFECT ONE YEAR WAR" (Video game)
- Key Animation - "Kidou Senshi Gundam" (Video game)
- Key Animation - "Serial Experiments Lain" (Video game)
- Key Animation - "Spiral Zone" (ep 5)!~

A notable mechanical and character designer for both anime and tokusatsu series.

He aspired a career in the industry after having seen [Space Battleship Yamato](https://anilist.co/anime/1650/), a franchise in which he would eventually serve as a director [in 2012](https://anilist.co/anime/12029/). His career began in 1978, debuting as a mechanical designer on [Toushou Daimos](https://anilist.co/anime/2816/), designing the enemy robots. Few years later in 1981, he made his tokusatsu debut on Robot 8-chan.

The following decade he worked on industry shaping series such as [Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/86/), [Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1089/) and [Patlabor](https://anilist.co/anime/324/). During this time he also had ties to Parallel Creation, a creative group led by sci-fi writer [Aritsune Toyota](https://anilist.co/staff/220367/). This led him to work as an illustrator on novels such as [Record of Lodoss War](https://anilist.co/manga/92655/), in which his designs were deeply influential for Japanese fantasy series.

In 2002, he directed [RahXephon](https://anilist.co/anime/165/), an anime original created by him. Izubuchi said that his attempt was to set a new standard for mecha anime, as well as to bring back aspects of '70s mecha shows like [Brave Raideen](https://anilist.co/anime/2128/).

A trademark in his mechanical designs is the Buchi-hole (ブチ穴), a series of round holes embedded, usually in a cluster pattern of three holes above and two below, located somewhere on the mecha.

Akihiro Yamada is a Japanese illustrator and manga artist. He was born in Kochi, Kochi Prefecture on the island of Shikoku in Japan, and now resides in Kyoto. Yamada is known for delicate images reminiscent of suiboku and depiction of fantasy subjects. He is the 1996 Seiun Award winner in art category.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Kadutaka_nue)

Kazutaka Miyatake is a visual artist and anime designer known for the mechanical design of the Macross TV series and a number of its continuations from Studio Nue, of which he is a founding member. He has also contributed to the mecha design of other series such as Mobile Suit Gundam SEED Destiny.

Kazutaka Miyatake has designed the spaceships of several famous anime series. His attention to detail and mechanical realism have made his designs still admired upon and used in anime series and related products after several years of their initial appearance.

__Birthplace:__ Osaka Prefecture, Japan

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Sakai_Sampo) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%A0%BA%E4%B8%89%E4%BF%9D)

Mitsuyasu Sakai is a Japanese critic, translator and science fiction writer.

Sakai graduated from Mikunigaoka High School, and he holds a Master's degree in Electronic Engineering from Kansai University. After working at NTT as an A.I. researcher, he became a sci-fi novel writer and translator. He also started handling scripts and sci-fi related work on anime. In 2018, he crowdfunded the production of a live-action film and managed to fund 19 million yen, which is the highest film production crowdfunding ever achieved in Japan. In 2021, he produced, directed and wrote a short film, title "Orbital Christmas." A novelization of the work was written by [Haruna Ikezawa](https://anilist.co/staff/95439/).

He holds a regular event on Live Wire called "Haruna Ikezawa & Miho Sakai's SF Anything Box" with aforementioend voice actress and essayist Haruna Ikezawa.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%9D%91%E6%9C%A8%E9%9D%96)

Yasushi Muraki is an animator and an occasional director affiliated with [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/).

Admired [Ichirou Itano](https://anilist.co/staff/103268/) and [Masami Oobari](https://anilist.co/staff/100660/), and became an animator. He is skilled in mechanical and action animation, and is one of three animators alongside [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/) and [Masami Gotou](https://anilist.co/staff/129865/) who are said to have fully mastered the "Itano Circus" drawing technique. He was invited to join the production of [Eureka Seven](https://anilist.co/anime/237/) by [Kenichi Yoshida](https://anilist.co/staff/103498/), who was in charge of character designs and became the special effects director of the series, fully demonstrating his skills.

(Source: Wikipedia)

Akihiro Yamada is a Japanese illustrator and manga artist. He was born in Kochi, Kochi Prefecture on the island of Shikoku in Japan, and now resides in Kyoto. Yamada is known for delicate images reminiscent of suiboku and depiction of fantasy subjects. He is the 1996 Seiun Award winner in art category.
